Evolution, EVO-LU-TION.

And whenever we hear this word and even if
we don’t hear it in the biological context,

I think what is probably the most misunderstood
concept in all of science and as we all know

is now turning into one of the most contentious
concepts, maybe not in science but in our

we imagine that something is changing, it
is evolving. And so when we, when people use

the word evolution in our every day context,
they think of this notion of change, that,

you know, this is going to test my drawing
ability, but they, you know see ahh, an ape,

you know, bent over. We’ve all seen this
picture at the natural museum and he is walking

back like that and his head is bent down and,
oh I’m doing my best, that’s the ape,

maybe he’s also wearing a hat. And then
they show this picture where he slowly slowly,

more and more upright and eventually, you
know he turns into some dude whose just walking

on his way to work, you know, also just as
happy and now he’s walking completely upright,

and you know, with some kind of implication
that walking upright is better than not walking

upright etc. etc., oh he doesn’t have a
tail anymore, we eliminate that.

This guy does have a tail, let me do it in
a appropriate width, this guys has a tail

so you’re going to have to excuse my drawing
skills. But we’ve all seen this if you’ve

ever gone to a natural history museum and
they’ll just make more and more upright

uhm apes and eventually you get to human beings
and its this idea that the apes somehow changed

into a human being. And, and, and I’ve seen
this in multiple contexts, even inside of

biology classes and even the scientific community
they’ll say- oh the apes evolved into the

human or the ape evolved into you know the
the the pre-human, the guy that almost stood

upright, you know the guy that was a little
bit hunched back but you know so he looked

a little bit like an ape and a little bit
like a human and so on and so forth.

And I want to be very clear here, even though
this process did happen, that you did have

creatures that over time accumulated changes
that uhm maybe their ancestors might have

looked more like this and eventually they
looked more like this, there was no, there
was no, active process going on called evolution.

It’s not like the ape said “ Gee, I would,
I would like my kids to look more like this

dude, so somehow I’m going to get my DNA
to get enough changes to look like this”

It’s not like the DNA knew, the DNA didn’t
say “ Hey it’s better to be walking than

to be you know kinda hunched backed like an
ape. And so therefore, I am going to try to

somehow spontaneously change into this dude.
That’s not what evolution is. It’s not

like you know, some people imagine that maybe
there was a tree, there’s a tree and on

that tree there’s a bunch of good fruit
at the top of the tree, there’s a bunch

of good fruit at the top of the tree, maybe
they’re apples, and then maybe you have

some type of cow like creature. Or maybe some
type of horse-like creature, who says “Gee,

I would like to get to those apples” and
that just because they want to get there,

or maybe the next generation, they keep trying
to raise their necks and after generation

after generation, their necks get longer and
longer and eventually they turn into Giraffes.

That is not what evolution is and that’s
not what it implies. Although sometimes the

the everyday notion of the word seems to make
us think that way. What evolution is and actually

this is the word I prefer to use, it’s natural
selection.

Natural selection! Actually let me write that
word down, NA-TURAL-SELEC-TION.

And literally what it mean is that any in
any population of living organisms, you’re

going to have some variation. And this is
a important key word here. Variation just

means look there’s some, there’s just
some change, if you if you look at, you know,

the kids in your school, you’ll see variation.
Some people are tall, some people are short,

some people have blonde hair, some people
have black hair, so on and so forth. There’s

always variation! And what natural selection
is, is this process that sometimes environmental

factors, will select for certain variations.
Some variations might not matter at all, but

some variations matter a lot. One example
that’s given in every biology book, but

it really is interesting is a, I believe they’re
called the pepper moth. And this was pre-industrial,

pre-industrial revolution England. That these
moths, that you know, some of the moths, were,

let me see if I can draw a moth, I have to
get the idea that they’re little. Let me

draw a couple of them. Let me draw a few peppered
moths!

A couple of peppred moths there, Let me draw
one more. So most peppered moths, there was

just this variation, some of them were, I
guess we could call them, more peppered than

others. And some of them might look like this.
You know they had, let me do other colors,

let me do it white, so it has spots like that.
Some of the might’ve looked more like that.

And maybe they had some black spots on them.
And then some of them might have been you

know almost, barely have any spots. You just
have this natural variation that you’ll

see in any population of animals you’ll
see some variation in colors.

Now they were all happy probably for thousands
of years, just this natural variation, it

was just a non important trait for these peppered
moths. But then all of a sudden the industrial

revolution happens in England, and all this
soot gets released from all of these, all

of these factories that are running these,
you know steam engines powered by coal. And

so all of a sudden all of the things that
once were grey or white, for example, maybe

some tree trunks, I’m going to draw some
tree trunks. Maybe there were some tree trunks

that used to look like this, you know maybe
it looked like a, maybe it kept a, maybe some

tree trunks used to look something like this.
And a peppered moth would be pretty ok, and

maybe there were some tree trunks that were
pretty dark. But all of a sudden the industrial

revolution happens, everything gets covered
with soot from the coal being burned. And

then all of a sudden all the trees look like
this, they’re just completely pitch black
or they are a lot darker than they were before.

Now all of a sudden you’ve had a major,
major change to these moths’ environment

and you have to think what, what is going
to select for these moths? Well, one thing

that might get these moths are birds and the
ability, the ability of the birds to see these

moths. So all of a sudden, if the environment
became a lot blacker than it was before, you

can guess what’s going to happen. The birds
are going to see, the birds are going to see

this dude a lot easier than they are going
to see this dude, cause this dude cause this

dude on a black background he’s going to
be a lot harder to see. Its not like the birds

won’t catch this guy they’ll catch all
of them but they’re going to catch this

guy a lot more frequently. So you can imagine
what happens if, if the birds start catching

these guys before they can reproduce or while
they’re reproducing what’s going to happen?

This guy, the darker dudes are going to reproduce
a lot more often and all of a sudden you’re

going to have a lot more moths that look like
this. You’re going to have a lot more of
these dudes.

So what happened here? Was there any design
or was there any active change by any of the

moths? Did any of the moths, I mean it looks
like a really smart thing to do to become

black right? Your, your surrounding became
black and you wait a couple of generations

of these moths and all of a sudden the moths
are black! And you might say wow those moths

are geniuses. They all somehow decided to
evolve into black moths in order to hide from

the birds more easily but that’s not what
happened. You had a bunch of, you had a lot

of variation in the peppered moth population.
And what happened was is that when everything

turned darker and darker, these dudes right
here and dudetes had a lot less success in

reproducing. These guys just reproduced more
and more and more, and these guys got eaten

up before they were able to reproduce and
maybe while they were reproducing so they

couldn’t produce as many offspring and then
this train just become dominant. And then

the peppered moth just became, you can kina
view it as a, black moth. Now you might say,

ok Sal, you know that’s one example, I need
more! This is natural selection, its purported

to apply to everything. It explains why, or
it purports to explain why we, why we evolved

from basic bacteria or maybe even self replicating
RNA, which I will talk about more in the future,

you know I need more evidence of this, I need
to see it in real time. And the best example
of this is really the Flu!

Is really the Flu. And I’ll do other videos
in the future on what viruses are and how

they replicate, and Viruses are actually fascinating
because its not even cleared that they are

alive. They’re literally just little buckets
of of DNA and sometimes RNA, which we’ll

learn is genetic information. And they’re
just contained in these viral, in these protein

containers, that are these neat geometrical
shapes. And that’s all they are, they really

don’t have, you know, they’re not like
regular living organisms that, that you know

actively move, and that actively have metabolisms
and all that. What they do is that they take

that little DNA and inject it into other things
that can process it and then they use that
DNA to produce more viruses.

But anyway, I could, we could a whole series
of videos on viruses. But the flu is a virus.

And what happens every year is you have a
a certain type of virus, a certain type of

virus. And they have some variation and I’ll
just make the variation by, I don’t know,

how many dots they have. How many dots they
have. And they infect lets say its a human

flue and they infect humans and slowly are
immune systems, which we can make a whole

set of vides on as well, start to recognize
the virus and are able to attack them before

they can do a lot of damage. So now you can
imagine what happens if lets say this is the

current flu, let me do all of them, they all
have these two dots, and that’s how, we’ll

talk in the future, what these dots are and
how they can be recognized. But lets say that’s

how our immune system recognized them. They
start realizing oh any time I get this little

green dude with two dots on it, that’s not
a good thing to have around so I’m going

to attack it in some ways and going to destroy
it before he infects my immune, my DNA and

all the rest. So you have a very strong natural
selection, once immune systems learn what

this virus is, and we’ll talk more about
what learning means for for a immune system,

that they’ll start attacking these guys
right, they’ll start attacking these guys.

But flu, you can kinda think of them as being
tricky, but they’re not really tricky. They’re

not sentient objects, but what they do do
is that they constantly change. So what you

have is in any flue population your always
having a little bit of change.

So maybe the great majority of them have those
two dots. But Maybe every now and then one

of them has one dot, one of them has three
dots and maybe that’s just a random mutation,

this just randomly happened, maybe one in
every, maybe this is one in every, I’ll

make up a number, one in every million of
these viruses have this only one dot instead

of two dots. But what’s going to happen
as soon as the human immune system gets used

to attacking the virus with the two red dots,
well then this guy isn’t going to have to

compete with the other virus capsules for
infecting people. He’s going to have people’s

DNA all to himself and so he/she or whatever
you want to call this virus, is then going

to be more successful. So by next year’s
flu season when everyone starts sneezing and

are able to spread it on door knobs and whatever
else again, this guy is going to be the new
flu virus.

So when you see this this process of every
year there’s a new flu virus that is evolution

and natural selection in real time. It is
happening it isn’t this thing that only

happens over eons and eons of time, although
most of the kind of the substantial things

we see in our lives or in ourselves are based
on these things that happened over eons and

eons of time. But it happens on a yearly basis.
Another example is if you think about antibiotics

and bacteria. Bacteria are these little cells
that move around and we’ll talk more about

them. They actually are definitely living.
They have metabolisms and whatever else. And

so when, and this is just nice to know. When
people talk about infections, it could either

be a viral infection, which are these things
that go and infect your DNA and then use your

cell mechanisms to reproduce or could be a
bacterial infection; which are literally little

cells which move around and release toxins
that make you sick and whatever else. So bacteria

these are what antibiotics kill. ANTI, ANTI-BIOTICS,
actually I don’t think there’s a hyphen.

ANTIBIOTICS. They attack bacteria. They kill
them. Now youv’e probably, if you know a

couple of doctors or whatever, and you say
hey I’m sick, I have a bacterial infection

give me some antibiotics, responsible doctors
says, I shouldn’t, no I won’t give you

antibiotics just willy nilly because what
happens is that the more antibiotics you use,

your more likely to create versions, and I
want to be very careful about the word create,

because your not actively creating them. But
lets say, and let me finish my sentence, you’re

your very likely to help select for antibiotic
resistant bacterias. Now how does that work?

So lets say a green, lets say that this is,
lets say that these are all bacteria and you

have gazillions of them right. Every now and
then you get one that’s slightly different,

right. That’s slightly different. Now in
a random population, in a population of bacteria

these will all make you equally sick and this
just some random difference in the bacteria

maybe on the DNA, some slight changes happened.
But whatever happened, these all are kind

of the bacteria you don’t want to get a
lot of them in your system, your immune system

can attack them and fight them off, but if
you get a lot of them they might kill you

or make you sick or whatever else. Now, if
everyone just starts using antibiotics when

they’re not sick, is or when they don’t
need to use them in a life or death situation

is that you might have an anitobiotic that
is really good at killing the green bacteria

but what if all of a sudden you kill a lot
of the green bacteria?

Well now the blue bacteria have the whole
ecosystem that before it was competing with

all these green dudes to like you know, get
it at your get all the good stuff inside of

your body. But now he’s all alone. And now
he can replicate willy nilly. So now he’s

going to replicate willy nilly. And obviously,
and this is once again he didn’t, it wasn’t

like there was any design, that there was
any intelligent process here that said, look

this bacteria should, you know I’m some
bacteria said I’m going to be a little smarter

and design myself to resist the resist this
antibiotic threat. No! There’s just these

random changes that happened and mutations
in viruses and bacteria happened frequently

and there are these random changes that happened
and this might be a one in a, you know, one

billion change. But all of a sudden if you
start killing off all the people that its

competing with this guy can start replicating
really fast, and then become the dominant

bacteria. Then all of a sudden , then all
of a sudden, that antibiotic that you know

that you had developed very carefully to destroy
the green dudes is useless. And you have this

superbug. You, if you, you might have heard
the world superbug. That’s what a superbug

is. Its not like it designed itself somehow,
its just that we got good at killing its competition

and so we allowed it to take over and so we
can’t IT, because all of the drugs are just

good at killing its competition. That these,
these bacteria are just keep mutating and

just keep mutating and if we use these antibiotics
a little heavily we’ll always be selecting

for the things that won’t be effected by
the antibiotics.

Well anyway I think I’ve spoken long enough
but this is a fascinating, fascinating topic

and I really wanted to make this my very first,
my very first I guess video or lecture on

biology because ifyou really went to, biology
is the study of life, we can talk about what

life is, whether viruses are living, what
not, but if you really want to study living

systems you can’t make any assumptions other
than natural selection. We could go to another

rplant where the creatures don’t have DNA
or where they have some other type of hereditary

uh um information stored in their cells. Or
they replicate some other way or they’re

not even carbon based, they’re silicone
based and if went to that type of a planet

in order to study the biology on that planet,
everything else we know about biology, about

viruses and DNA would be useless. But if we
do understand this one concept this one concept

of natural selection, that your environment
will select, and its not, there’s no active

process here, its just random stuff happened
and the randomly select for random changes

and over large swaths of time, and these are
unimaginably large swaths of time, those,

those changes essentially accumulate and they
might accumulate into fairly fairly significant
things.

We’ll talk more about this in another video,
see you soon!
